{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3485178,"name":"Andrew Askins","username":"askins4robots","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/askins4robots/{size}/245779_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-17T00:23:02.119Z","cooked":"

Hey there! Programming mentor for team 7196 here. This is our first year using Swerve and we’re trying to get setup with YAGSL and a standard MaxSwerve setup. I’m having trouble with my encoder values and I think it has to do my config.

Based on the behavior I’m seeing, it seems like the library is interpreting my relative encoder values as absolute encoder values and vice versa.

Does anyone have advice on how to set the encoder config for the standard MaxSwerve setup using the attached encoders through the SparkMax? Our configs all look like this at the moment:

"encoder": {
  "type": "attached",
  "id": -1,
  "canbus": null
}

I have also tried using 0 and the CanID for the motor controller as the can id, neither of which have fixed the issue. Any help would be appreciated!

@nstrike a friend said you might be able to help?

You can check out YAGSL’s maxswerve example for reference

github.com

YAGSL-Example/src/main/deploy/swerve/maxSwerve/modules at main ·...

Yet Another General Swerve Library Example Project - BroncBotz3481/YAGSL-Example

an example module configuration would be

{
  "drive": {
    "type": "sparkmax_neo",
    "id": 42,
    "canbus": null
  },
  "angle": {
    "type": "sparkmax_neo550",
    "id": 4,
    "canbus": null
  },
  "encoder": {
    "type": "attached",
    "id": 0,
    "canbus": null
  },
  "inverted": {
    "drive": false,
    "angle": false
  },
  "absoluteEncoderInverted": true,
  "absoluteEncoderOffset": 301.3301969,
  "location": {
    "front": -12,
    "left": 12
  }
}

also,

askins4robots:

"id": -1,

you can’t actually have a negative can id. you don’t need to set one for the encoder either, as it’s attached, so just leave that at 0

There’s also this generator tool that might help you configure all your modules:
https://broncbotz3481.github.io/YAGSL-Example/

Can you update to 2025.2.1 and try again. This is a known problem with 2025.0.0

I followed the example configs, and was still getting the problem. Saw one team using -1 and thought I would try that in case it’s something YAGSL was looking for. I’ll switch it back to 0. Good to know officially that you don’t need to set one, was having trouble verifying that from the docs.

Looks like from @nstrike’s comment that this is a known issue. I’ll update our library and report back.

Thanks for the reply! I’ll update to 2025.2.1 tomorrow and report back. I think we’re currently on 2025.1.1, but possibly a beta version.

@nstrike we updated to 2025.2.2 and it seems to have fixed the relative encoder issue. However we’re seeing some additional behavior that feels like it could be caused by another library bug.

Specifically when we try to turn using the driveFieldOriented function and an AngularVelocity two of the wheels are turning to the correct position while the other two are always 90 degrees off causing the robot to move diagonally instead of turning. This doesn’t seem to be an encoder offset issue, and as best we can tell all of our config is correct. Driving using the same function without rotation is working as expected.

We are working through the 8 steps, but they don’t seem like they should fix this issue. Any advice?

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-01-18T18:21:39.141Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":15,"readers_count":14,"score":3.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":482196,"topic_slug":"configuring-encoders-with-yagsl","display_username":"Andrew Askins","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/techtigers7196/frc7196_2025","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - techtigers7196/frc7196_2025","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71425,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Andrew (Programming Mentor)"},"post_url":"/t/configuring-encoders-with-yagsl/482196/8","custom_user_title":"Andrew (Programming Mentor)","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3486904,"name":"Andrew Askins","username":"askins4robots","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/askins4robots/{size}/245779_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-18T20:54:34.406Z","cooked":"

Found the issue! All of our module distances were positive, which was throwing off the math. Fixed that and the system seems to be working as expected!
